data.event: Acceptance notification by: 3 July 2000
We have scheduled 42 sessions -- 63 hours
Had >150 submissions.
Notable early bird savings.
This conference was later cancelled.
Due to financial/producer issues, the ACEU2001 conference was cancelled for Dublin. CFPs were collected.
Begin date is approximate!
Early bird discounts featured.
Was extended by http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/www-announce/200210.mbox/ajax/%3c3D9DE70C.B40AA76A@apache.org%3e
Early bird was featured.
There were multiple levels of early bird pricing with various discounts.
Logo contest held; winner gets discounted pass to the Fabulous Alexis Park Hotel!
Deadline extended.
Early bird savings were significant.
Super Early Bird discount ended on 23-Oct.
Various levels of early bird discounts offered.
Early bird savings were significant.
Early Bird savings ended 15-Sep.
Notable early bird savings.
Email sent 21-March with deadline extended to 27-March
Started earlier than 12-July... need to confirm open date.
CFP held for ACUS05. Speakers to be notified 26 August.
Early bird savings were notable.
Estimated start date.
Estimated end date.
End date extended at last minute from original 23-July deadline.
Yes, this was an incredibly short CFP. I can't believe it all worked out anyway!
Early bird was supposed to end 12-Oct, but was extended.
Early bird was extended to 22-Sep with this email.
This short CFP was needed to ensure all submissions were in before our planning meeting at ApacheCon Europe 2008.
This short CFP was needed to ensure all submissions were in before our planning meeting at ApacheCon US 2008.
Committer rate price bump was minimized.
Was extended one week
Extended until 17-Oct.
Email sent on 26-Sep, expired on 3-Oct.
Email sent on 20-Aug, expired on 29-Aug.
Email sent on 8-Aug, expired (originally) on 15-Aug.
Early bird planned to expire 7-Feb.
Produced by C2Net in San Francisco, with 53 speakers this was very strongly attended for a first show.
No ApacheCon was run in 1999 due to the effort required to plan a conference; instead, we planned US and European conferences for 2000.

Produced by Camelot Communications in Orlando, FL, this event 4 tracks of technical talks and included training classes. Keynote speakers included Wil Wheaton, Cory Doctorow, Tim Bray, and Jaron Lanier. Notable sponsors include Collab.net, Covalent, IBM, and Sun, names seen frequently at ApacheCon.

Produced by Camelot Communications in London, UK, this was a highly memorable conference. There were 3 tracks of technical talks and simultaneous BOF tracks available. Keynote speakers included Douglas Adams.
Produced by Camelot Communications in Santa Clara, CA, with 3 tracks of technical talks and simultaneous BOFs. Keynote speakers included Jon 'maddog' Hall and David Brin.

Produced by Security Travel in Las Vegas, NV at the fabulous Alexis Park Hotel with 4 technical tracks, with BOFs in the evenings. This began the short-lived tradition of having ApacheCon the same week as COMDEX. Keynote speakers included Tim O'Reilly and Richard Thieme.

Produced by Security Travel in Las Vegas, NV continuing at the fabulous Alexis Park Hotel, with 4 technical tracks, and BOFs in evenings. The ApacheCon Wiki began. Keynote speakers included Chris Pirillo and Doc Searls.

Produced by Security Travel in Las Vegas, NV we returned once again to the even more fabulous Alexis Park Hotel, with 4 technical tracks, with BOFs in the evenings. Keynote speakers included Miguel De Icaza and Doc Searls. The ever popular Lightning Talks began!
Produced by Software & Support Verlag in Stuttgart, Germany, with 4 technical tracks, with BOFs in the evenings. Keynote speakers included Dr. Horst Zuse, Danese Cooper, and Jan Wildeboer.

Produced by FCP in San Diego, CA, with 4 technical tracks, with BOFs in the evenings. Keynote speakers included Cory Doctorow, Jaron Lanier, and Tim Bray. World premier screening of "FUD", a documentary movie about open source.

Produced by Software & Support Verlag in Dublin, Ireland, June 26-30, with 4 tracks including a special Business track, with BOFs in the evenings. Keynote speakers included Robert Burke and Mark Shuttleworth.

Co-produced by the Lanka Software Foundation, lug.lk, and The Linux Center in Colombo, Sri Lanka. This first ApacheCon in Asia featured 2 tracks, BOFs, and Lightning Talks, with Ken Coar as keynote speaker.

Produced by SCP in Austin, TX, with a record number of speakers. There were 5 tracks plus BOFs, premiering the Business Track and the Open Source Legal and Licensing track. Keynote speakers included Dr. Cliff Stoll, Dr. Patrick Ball, and Howard Tayler.
Produced by SCP in Amsterdam, with 4 tracks, BOFs, and the first Fast Feather track ever. Keynote speakers included Steven Pemberton, Dr. Margo Seltzer,
Produced by SCP in Atlanta, GA, featuring 4 tracks plus a multi-day Business track and the Fast Feather track. Keynote speakers included Doc Searls, Jim Gettys, Ora Lassila
Produced by OS Summit LLC in Hong Kong, this joint conference with the Eclipse Foundation was cancelled due to unfortunate circumstances.
Produced by SCP in Amsterdam again with 3 tracks, and Keynotes from Cliff Schmidt, Rishab Aiyer Ghosh, Roy Fielding. Now with Crowdvine social networking.
Produced by SCP in New Orleans with 5 full tracks, a live jazz band, and Keynotes from Sam Ramji, David Recordon, Shahani Weerawarana.
Produced by SCP in Amsterdam with 4 tracks and Keynotes from Raghu Ramakrishnan, James Governor, and The ASF Founder's Panel. Crowdvine continues.
Held in Oakland, CA, this featured bigger and better events than ever before.
Coming to Atlanta, GA, with PMCs helping drive track selection.
Held in Vancouver BC, Canada, with 5 tracks and great attendance.
Held in Sinsheim, Germany.
Held in Portland, OR.
Held in Denver, CO.
Held in Budapest, Hungary.
Held in Austin, TX.
Held in Budapest, Hungary.
Held in Budapest, Hungary.
Held in Vancouver, BC.
Held in Vancouver, BC.
Held in Seville, Spain.
Held in Seville, Spain.

Teleconference held by Roy to report on incorporation, approve bylaws, elect officers, and created the Apache Conference Committee, or "Concom" and HTTP Server.

6. Special Orders A. Effective date of incorporation By general consent, it was agreed that the official effective date of incorporation for the Apache Software Foundation is to be set as June 1, 1999.
James Davidson appointed VP, Jakarta; Dirk-Willem van Gulik appointed VP, XML.
Doug MacEachern appointed VP, Perl-Apache

event.title: JCP Resolution passed (only implement free specs)
event.caption: JCP Resolution passed (only implement free specs)

data.event: ... NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that The Apache Software Foundation will no longer participate in the development of implementations or interface standards that cannot be completely implemented and distributed as open source software, without royalties or fees of any kind, by nonprofit and educational organizations; and be it further ...

data.event: Ben Laurie and Mark Cox are original members.
Jim Jagielski appointed VP, and members include: Aaron Bannert, Nicola Ken Barozzi, Ken Coar, Roy T. Fielding, B. W. Fitzpatrick, Greg Stein, Sander Striker
